channel.title: This American Life
channel.description: This American Life is a weekly public radio show, heard by 2.2 million people on more than 500 stations. Another 2.5 million people download the weekly podcast. It is hosted by Ira Glass, produced in collaboration with Chicago Public Media, delivered to stations by PRX The Public Radio Exchange, and has won all of the major broadcasting awards.
channel.itunes:author: This American Life
channel.itunes:subtitle: This American Life is a weekly public radio show, heard by 2.2 million people on more than 500 stations. Another 2.5 million people download the weekly podcast.

item.title: 598: My Undesirable Talent
item.description: San Francisco’s Spider-Man burglar was remarkable. He dropped into buildings from skylights, leapt 10 feet from one roof to another. But mostly, his talent got him into trouble. This week, his story, and stories of other undesirable talents.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: San Francisco’s Spider-Man dropped into buildings from skylights and leapt 10 feet from one roof to another. But mostly, his talent got him into trouble.
item.itunes:summary: San Francisco’s Spider-Man burglar was remarkable. He dropped into buildings from skylights, leapt 10 feet from one roof to another. But mostly, his talent got him into trouble. This week, his story, and stories of other undesirable talents.

item.title: 787: Baby's First Christmas
item.description: People experiencing Christmas in brand new ways, giving the holiday even more meaning.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: People experiencing Christmas in brand new ways, giving the holiday even more meaning.
item.itunes:summary: People experiencing Christmas in brand new ways, giving the holiday even more meaning.

item.title: 757: The Ghost in the Machine
item.description: People use machines to find people they lost.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: People use machines to find people they lost.
item.itunes:summary: People use machines to find people they lost.

item.title: 402: Save the Day
item.description: Stories about one person single-handedly taking charge of a situation gone wrong.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Stories about one person single-handedly taking charge of a situation gone wrong.
item.itunes:summary: Stories about one person single-handedly taking charge of a situation gone wrong.

item.title: 786: It's a Game Show!
item.description: Something we’ve never done before: true stories told in the form of a game show.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Something we’ve never done before: true stories told in the form of a game show.
item.itunes:summary: Something we’ve never done before: true stories told in the form of a game show.

item.title: 785: Through the Looking Glass
item.description: People trying to coax each other across the line, from one side to the other.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: People trying to coax each other across the line, from one side to the other.
item.itunes:summary: People trying to coax each other across the line, from one side to the other.

item.title: 784: Mapmaker, Mapmaker, Make Me a Map
item.description: Not long ago, Republicans in Ohio passed a constitutional amendment to end gerrymandering in the state. And then a funny thing happened. The same Ohio Republicans drew electoral maps that violated their own constitutional amendment. They’ll be using them in this week’s midterm elections. We try to understand how that could happen.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: How Ohio Republicans drew electoral maps that violated their own constitutional amendment.
item.itunes:summary: Not long ago, Republicans in Ohio passed a constitutional amendment to end gerrymandering in the state. And then a funny thing happened. The same Ohio Republicans drew electoral maps that violated their own constitutional amendment. They’ll be using them in this week’s midterm elections. We try to understand how that could happen.

item.title: 783: Kids These Days
item.description: We hear from kids who are dealing with some of the country’s most contentious debates. Debates that are supposedly about them.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: We hear from kids who are dealing with some of the country’s most contentious debates. Debates that are supposedly about them.
item.itunes:summary: We hear from kids who are dealing with some of the country’s most contentious debates. Debates that are supposedly about them.

item.title: 782: Family Dig
item.description: Two people go on excavations of their families’ pasts. Including the first episode of the new podcast, “We Were Three,” hosted by our longtime producer, Nancy Updike, and from Serial Productions and The New York Times.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Two people go on excavations of their families’ pasts.
item.itunes:summary: Two people go on excavations of their families’ pasts. Including the first episode of the new podcast, “We Were Three,” hosted by our longtime producer, Nancy Updike, and from Serial Productions and The New York Times.

item.title: 781: Watching the Watchers
item.description: People taking it upon themselves to keep an eye on those in charge.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: People taking it upon themselves to keep an eye on those in charge.
item.itunes:summary: People taking it upon themselves to keep an eye on those in charge.
